Neurocomputing

Volume 611 , 1 January 2025 , 128629

SCGC : Self-supervised contrastive graph clustering

Author links open overlay panel , ,
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neucom.2024.128629 Get rights and content
Under a Creative Commons license
open access

Abstract

Graph clustering discovers groups or communities within networks. Increasingly, models use autoencoders to achieve effective clustering combined with Graph Neural Networks (GNN) for structure incorporation. However, GNNs based on convolution or attention variants lack dynamic fusion, suffer from over-smoothing, noise, node heterophily, are computationally expensive and typically require the complete graph being present. Instead, we propose SCGC, capable of dynamic soft structure fusion via augmentation-less edge-contrastive loss. Further, we propose SCGC*, with a more expressive novel distance metric, Influence, and our Influence Augmented Contrastive (IAC) loss, requiring only half the model parameters. Our models, SCGC and SCGC*, dynamically fuse discriminative node representations, jointly refine soft cluster assignments, completely eliminate convolutions and attention of traditional GNNs, use only simple linear units, and yet efficiently incorporate structure. They are impervious to layer depth; robust to over-smoothing, incorrect edges and heterophily; scalable by batching; augmentation-less; relaxes the homophily assumption and trivially parallelizable. We improve significantly over the state-of-the-art on a wide range of benchmarks, including images, sensor data, text, and citation networks, with superb efficiency. Specifically, 20% on ARI and 18% on NMI for DBLP; overall 55% reduction in training time and overall, 81% reduction on inference time. code: https://github.com/gayanku/SCGC .

1. Introduction

Research into graphs has been receiving increased attention due to the high expressiveness and pervasiveness of graph structured data [1] . Its unique non-Euclidean data structure is ideally suited to represent diverse feature rich domains for machine learning [2] . Many real-world tasks, such as the analysis of citation networks, social networks, and protein-protein interaction, all rely on graph-data mining skills. Graph clustering discovers groups or communities within networks by partitioning similar nodes into disjoint groups [2] . Clustering has been used for images [3] , [4] , text [5] , [6] and social networks [7] , [8] . To date, deep clustering methods based on Auto Encoders (AE) [6] , [9] , [10] , [11] have achieved state-of-the-art performance.
In order to exploit the rich information present in the structure, many researchers [2] , [6] , [11] , [12] have combined Graph Neural Network (GNN)s with AEs [13] . Although these models achieved state-of-the-art in clustering, the reliance on GNN for structure incorporation is challenging due to (a) over-smoothing, (b) noisy neighbors (heterophily), and (c) the suspended animation problem [1] . GNNs stack layers [14] to facilitate interaction between nodes that are not directly connected, leading to over-smoothing where node representations become indistinguishable due to too much mixing [15] . To alleviate this, most GNNs are shallow and cannot benefit from deep models. Models such as GCNII [16] and FDGATII [1] can achieve higher depths but still require appropriate depth to be pre-determined, and use computationally expensive convolutions or softmax attention operations.
It is well known that structural information represents the underlying dependencies among nodes [6] . However, such dependencies can be direct (local) or indirect (non-local) dependencies of one or more orders of arbitrary compositions. Thus, it is non-trivial to approximate such an unpredictable latent structure with a fixed pre-chosen convolutional or other layer structure. Recently, there is a shift towards more simple and efficient model implementations [4] , [15] , [17] . While contrastive loss has been used [4] , [18] to learn graph embeddings, they use expensive augmentations and contain a form of convolution based GNN.
In this work, as shown in Fig. 1 , we demonstrate how both the GNN and AE in prior work can be eliminated from main training loop and inference, whilst still obtaining state-of-the-art in self supervised graph clustering. We incorporate structure using augmentation-less edge-contrastive loss and avoid complex fusion operators. We are also able to use a simpler single self supervision. Essentially, our proposed deep clustering method learns a dynamic soft structure fusion via augmentation-less edge-contrastive loss, to enforce graph structure and clustering optimization, instead of attempting to match the latent node dependency dynamics.
We propose 2 models. SCGC and SCGC*. In SCGC, we use 1-hop information for soft structure incorporation and retain the AE as in prior work. In SCGC*, we use aggregated multi-hop information (which we term as Influence) via our proposed IAC loss and discard the AE. Specifically, in SCGC* we use minimally pre-trained (30 epochs, sub-batched) embeddings to effectively and efficiently replace the AE during training. For structure and feature fusion, we introduce a novel contrastive loss metric, Influence, and define I nfluence A ugmented C ontrastive (IAC) loss with a relaxed homophilic assumption. Additionally, we use a confident soft label based self-supervision.
SCGC is computationally efficient as it consists of simple linear layer (MLP)s. There are no expensive convolutions, softmax operations or augmentations. There is no need to carry adjacency information through the model, decoupling the model structure from the latent node dependency structure. Thus, the SCGC structure can remain unchanged across diverse data, as we demonstrate using benchmark data sets from image, text, and graph modalities. SCGC is ideal for edge and resource constraint applications. By only having soft structure fusion via augmentation-less contrastive loss, SCGC is more robust to noisy edges. Further, as we are using a probability distribution based self-supervision mechanism, the model is also robust to feature noise and class/label noise, i.e., heterophily. Our main contributions are:
  • •
    We propose a novel deep clustering model, SCGC, which eliminates the need for a traditional GNN in graph clustering. SCGC completely decouples structure from the graph and moves it to a convenient loss function.
  • •
    We introduce the Influence metric as a simple yet powerful proxy for complex graphs structure, provide an efficient procedure for computation, and propose a novel I nfluence A ugmented C ontrastive (IAC) loss with theoretical insights and demonstrate empirical superiority.
  • •
    Experiments on 6 benchmarks of images, sensor data, text, and citation network data shows SCGC outperform state-of-the-art graph clustering methods in accuracy, training and inference efficiency.
Despite minor differences, existing deep graph clustering uses an AE-based reconstruction loss minimization [20] . We show that an AE is only necessary for minimal initialization (30 epochs), and our training and inference phases require no AE. Also, by learning a structure-aware transformation, graph information is not needed for inference; thus, our model is robust to nodes’ missing connections. Furthermore, most contrastive models use SimCLR’s [16] Noise Contrastive Estimation (NCE) approach requiring augmented views, typically per epoch and assume independent and identically distributed (IID) data. Other models assume connected nodes are similar: homophily. Instead, we use learnt soft local–global structure fusion via our novel Influence metric. By using an effective loss-driven model to impart structure, we are able to use a simple MLP, avoiding expensive augmentations, convolutions and attention mechanisms. The resulting model is more efficient and faster. SCGC manages images, text, and graphs equally well.

2. Related work

2.1. Auto encoders (AE)

An AE can be applied to purely unsupervised environments, including clustering [2] . Early work on graph clustering relied purely on node features: [9] introduced the classical AE; [21] introduced deep embedded clustering method (DEC) that incorporated KL divergence into the AE; [10] combined a reconstruction loss to improve DEC. However, the complexity of graph topological structure imposes significant challenges on clustering [2] which AEs alone cannot solve.

2.2. Incorporating graph structure

A GNN performs node aggregation based on the neighborhood structure to obtain effective low dimensional embedding vectors [13] . GNN variants attempting to build effective and efficient models mainly differ in how the aggregation and subsequent combining of the node features is done [1] : Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) [14] uses convolution [22] ; GraphSage [23] uses max-pooling and Graph Attention Network (GAT) [24] uses attention.
In order to benefit from rich structural information, GNNs have been combined with AE: [12] proposed the graph auto encoder (GAE) and its variational variant (VGAE) by applying convolution [22] to an AE [9] ; [2] proposed DAEGC which used graph attention [24] with GAE; [5] proposed ARGA by introducing an adversarial regularizer to GAE. Recent work, [6] , [11] , [19] , as summarized in Fig. 1 , demonstrated benefits of decoupling the AE (features) and GNN (structure) components. These models, SDCN, AGCN, and DFCN, are powerful deep clustering models that exploit multimodality to generate discriminative embeddings. Specifically, [6] proposed SDCN which coupled DEC and GCN via a fixed delivery operator and reconstructed the features rather than the adjacency matrix; DFCN [19] added dynamic fusion of features and structure for self-supervision guidance in SDCN; [11] proposed AGCN by extending SDCN with a more flexible attention-based delivery operator and used multi-scale information. AGCN shows that features from different modalities should not be considered to have equal importance when fusing features. Within layers, it adaptively fuses features of different modalities. It also adaptively fuses layers. Although these models achieved remarkable improvements, and state-of-the-art performance in clustering, they rely on a GNN for structure incorporation. Furthermore, while DFCN uses triplet guided optimization, AGCN using only a dual guided optimization can achieve a better clustering performance. Thus, it is unclear if incorporating complex multi-modal fusion mechanisms is beneficial or disadvantageous for effective clustering.

2.3. Towards simpler graph models

Recently, there has been a shift towards more simple and efficient model implementations: [15] proposed SGC by successively removing activation layers and adding a pre-computed th power adjacency matrix to capture non-neighbor relations; [25] proposed FSGNN by decoupling the node feature aggregation from the GNN layer depth by using an array of pre-computed th power adjacency metrics; MLP-Mixer [17] , exclusively based on MLPs, attains competitive scores on image classification benchmarks; Graph-MLP [4] uses an MLP for graph citation networks; C-SWMs [26] uses an MLP for compositional objects.

2.4. Traditional contrastive loss

Contrastive learning is a self-supervised learning method that learns to distinguish similar representations (positives) from others (negatives) [27] . When no labels are available, augmented samples can be used as positives, while negatives are randomly selected from the entire pool of samples [20] . Maximizing agreement between such two augmented samples by assuming IID data is often used in vision [15] , [16] , [28] , pioneered by SimCLR’s [16] NCE approach. NCE has been extended to graphs, by creating a whole new graph as the augmented representation [3] , [18] ), typically per epoch, assuming IID data; GraphCL [18] uses contrastive learning on augmented views; [3] incorporates latent category information to reduce the intra-cluster variance but can only be used for image clustering; [26] uses contrastive loss between successive images to learn a delta for object detection; [24] contrasts with nodes from a corrupted graph. Other contrastive self-supervised methods (GraphSAGE [23] , Graph-MLP [4] ) adopt the homophily hypothesis, which states that connected nodes should be adjacent in the embedding space [4] , [27] . While successful, the homophily hypothesis can emphasize direct proximity of nodes over topological information [18] , [29] . Notably, the success of DGI is attributed to its ability to incorporate global and local parts of the input [27] .
In summary, prior works either use augmented images or graphs, rely on the homophily assumption, contain a form of GNN, or require supervision. Additionally, these models are specifically designed for either image, text or graph data. However, applying these methods to the clustering task still remains challenging [3] . The underlying Jensen–Shannon divergence of most contrastive graph embedding models can fail under disjoint positives [30] , which is more pronounced in clustering.

3. Proposed model

For any two nodes and of a graph, without any loss of generality assuming node is an arbitrary number of hops away, neighborhood information from node needs to pass via intermediary nodes to reach , as illustrated in Fig. 2 (a). In order to accomplish this, GNN architectures carry and use structural information as an adjacency matrix or via message passing during the training and inference stages. Additionally, stacked layers are used to increase the receptive field and reach multi-hop nodes. However, such a combination blurs the distinction between the importance of features [25] . It also results in complex structure and heavy computation [4] in current state-of-the-art models, as seen in Fig. 1 .
Instead we propose a single combined value to represent all the interactions of . Essentially, a single scalar as shown in Fig. 2 (a), denoted by . This can tremendously simplify the graph structure by replacing the graph with a collection of values, one scalar per actual graph edge . As real world graphs are usually extremely sparse and the adjacency matrix is mostly zero [31] , using edges improves scalability and efficiency further. As a result, GNN architectures do not need layers or larger receptive depth to capture important multi-hop neighborhood information. The resulting models are simpler and more effective and do not over fit. We term this composite of the interactions as Influence.
Influence is able to capture local and global structure effectively and is resilient to heterophily. Generally, GNN architectures find it challenging to identify at which depth (or hop) is the connected neighbor information most informative for capturing local and global structure. Different datasets show varying levels of homophily and heterophily. As a result, without any prior information, selecting a depth (hop) can be suboptimal. For example, 1-hop designs are more suitable for homophilic datasets where nodes linked to each other are more likely to be similar [4] , [27] . For heterophilic datasets which are more likely to have nodes with different labels connected together, researchers have proposed using fixed hop designs [6] , [11] , [19] , or proposed complex designs to learn from a mixture of hops by stacking layers [25] . As seen in Fig. 2 (a), using the combined interaction makes no assumption of any specific hop, making all hop information accessible for learning.
Computing Influence is not trivial, due to inter-dependencies. For example, node is also affected by nodes and some proportion of this is combined with node ’s effect when passing though . As all nodes will have other nodes affecting them, a computationally simple and efficient way of obtaining Influence is needed. In Section 3.1.1 we propose an elegant and simple mechanism for computing Influence, based on properties of matrices and sparsity of graph edges. In Section 3.1 we show the how Influence metric can be used as a loss function, namely IAC. Finally, we derive the proposed SCGC architecture which uses IAC loss for structure and a single KL divergence based self-supervision for clustering. Clustering is fundamentally unsupervised [32] while MLPs are usually supervised.
Distinct from previous GNN architectures, SCGC does not have a GNN, and uses a simple and computationally efficient MLP for graph clustering using IAC loss for structure and a KL divergence based self-supervision. IAC is augmentation-less and edge-contrastive unlike most contrastive losses. Furthermore, unlike prior state-of-the-art models that use multi-modal fusion, SCGC uses a single modality, avoiding the need for expensive multiple optimizations and end point fusion, but achieving better results as shown in Table 2 . Additionally, as shown in Fig. 6 , we achieve a higher efficiency.

3.1. Influence Augmented Contrastive (IAC) loss

As seen in Fig. 2 (a), graphs benefit from the unique ability where non-adjacent nodes at multiple depths can have arbitrary dissimilar and additive effects on a node. By using Influence, defined in the previous section, we can capture these additive effects from both the local and global neighborhood more generally and broadly for a given depth . While it can carry richer information, importantly, Influence relaxes the homophily assumption by incorporating indirect distant nodes. Prior GNN models naively assume a fixed depth relationship, i.e. a single obtained via hyper parameter searches. Layers of a typical GNN attempt to exploit this feature with a rigid layer structure. However, this layer structure needs to align with the latent influence structures. Further, GNN layers are universally applied to all nodes, thus incorrectly assuming all nodes get the same influence from different depth effects (essentially the assumption that there is only one fixed ). As a result, GNN models are often suboptimal. Furthermore, most GNN models cannot exceed 2 layers in depth due to over smoothing, which models such as FDGATII [1] and GCNII [16] attempt to solve. Influence is a simple, efficient alternative.
We use Influence as weighting factor in the specific but popular contrastive loss [4] to formulate IAC loss for the th node as: (1) where denotes the temperature parameter, is the influence of the connection between node and , and . Currently, we use all nodes , rather than a batch , thus . (We discuss batching in Section 3.5 .)
Essentially, for each node, its cumulative -hop neighbor influence is used to distinguish positive samples, which we contrast with all nodes. IAC loss encourages influential nodes to be closer than the non-influential nodes in the embedding space.
Fig. 2 (b) illustrates formulation of IAC loss. In the next two subsections, we outline how cumulative influence can be computed and provide details on our similarity measurement, i.e. .

3.1.1. Determining influence

Higher-order relationships and higher-order proximity between nodes in a graph is obtained from powers of the adjacency matrix. Raising adjacency matrix to r-th power provides information about the higher-order connectivity between nodes at the th distance (or depth or hop) of the graph [4] , [31] .
For the normalized adjacency matrix : (2) where is the self-connection and is the diagonal matrix with , the th power provides the strength of the th hop relationship between nodes and [4] .
Different from all previous works, we propose computing the influence as an additive form of all node relationships up to a given depth , rather than limiting it to some arbitrary single th hop neighborhood. Specifically, we define the th cumulative power of the normalized adjacency matrix as Influence , as seen in Fig. 2 (a). Thus: (3)
Importantly, contains the aggregated set of all previous neighborhood hop relationships from . Fig. 3 is a visualization of the IAC process. Powers of normalized adjacency matrix , up to are aggregated to obtain .
Intuitively, Each power of the adjacency matrix represents the number of paths of a specific length between pairs of nodes in the graph. Specifically, the -th edge of gives the number of -length walks between nodes and . More walks indicates more ways to travel between pair and higher connectivity. By summing up these powers, Influence aggregates information about paths of various lengths, capturing the overall connectivity and structure of the graph. Summing up powers up to a certain depth captures cumulative connectivity between nodes within a distance of hops, spanning from local to global structural information.
Computing needs only be done once, prior to training, using the adjacency matrix, with very little overhead. In large graphs, sparse implementations can be used to compute . Real-world graphs are usually extremely sparse and the adjacency matrix is mostly zero [31] . Furthermore, computation is completely outside of the model leaning process, does not involve expensive tensor operations, and the edge computation can easily be parallelized.

3.2. Self supervised clustering by confidence boosting

Graph clustering is essentially unsupervised. To this end, we use probability distribution-derived confident soft labels as a self- supervision mechanism for cluster enhancement, as shown in Fig. 2 (c).
Similar to existing work [2] , [10] , [19] , we first obtain the soft cluster assignments probabilities where is the cluster, for embedding and cluster center , using the Student’s -distribution [33] as a kernel to measure the similarity, in order to handle differently scaled clusters and for computational convenience [2] , as follows: (8) where, cluster centers are initialized by -means on embeddings from the pre-trained AE and is the Student’s -distribution’s degree of freedom. We use as the distribution of the cluster assignments of all samples and keep =1 for all experiments, as in prior work [6] , [11]
Nodes closer to a cluster center have higher soft assignment probabilities in . By raising to the second power and by normalizing, we define a target distribution that emphasizes the confident assignments, which is defined as: (9) where is the soft cluster frequency of centroid .
In order to make the data representation closer to cluster centers and improve cluster cohesion, we minimize the KL divergence loss between and distributions, which forces the current distribution to approach the more confident target distribution . We self-supervise cluster assignments 1 by using distribution to target distribution , which then supervises the distribution in turn by minimizing the KL divergence as: (10)
KL divergence updates models more gently and lessens severe disturbances on the embeddings [6] . Further, it can accommodate both the structural and feature optimization targets of SCGC.

H e n c k ∈ R n × d k and H ˆ d e c k ∈ R n × d ˆ k are the encoder and decoder outputs from the k t h layer. On completion of the pre training, we obtain Z = H ˆ d e c 0 = H e n c K and use K-means to obtain the cluster centers μ .

3.4. Final proposed models

Our preliminary experiments showed that, using IAC, once acceptable centroids μ are available, the feature reconstruction objective is redundant. The AE can be replaced with only the encoder (MLP) in Eq. (11) , halving the parameter count and training effort. Thus, we propose two model variants, AE-based SCGC and MLP-based SCGC* as, (12) SCGC : L = α l o s s n c ( K , τ ) + β l o s s c l u s t e r + l o s s r e c o n , SCGC ∗ : L = α l o s s i a c ( K , τ ) + β l o s s c l u s t e r , where α > 0 is the hyperparameter that balances structure incorporation and β > 0 controls the cluster optimization.

3.5. Complexity analysis

Given the input data dimension d and dimensions of the AE layers as d 1 , d 2 , … , d L , following [6] , the size of weight matrix of the first encoder layer is W e n c 1 ∈ R d × d 1 . With an input data size N , the time complexity is O 1 = O ( N d 2 d 1 2 . . . d L 2 ) for SCGC-AE and O 1 ∗ = O ( N d 2 d 1 2 . . . d L / 2 2 ) for SCGC*-AE. Assuming K clusters, from Eq. (8) , the time complexity is O 2 = O ( N K + N log N ) following [21] .
For contrastive loss, we compute ‖ z ‖ 2 2 and z i ⋅ z j for all N . Thus, the time complexity is O 3 = O ( N N d z ) where d z is the embedding dimension. While this results in a theoretical time complexity of O ( N 2 ) , given that Z ⋅ Z T is symmetrical, we only need to compute half of the result, and as the transpose of a matrix is the same matrix with indices swapped, caching can have over twice the impact. [31] presents an algorithm to obtain a similarity matrix that preserves graph transitive relationships which is formulated as matrix chain multiplications, so that applying random projection has a linear time cost. Lastly, batching (see Section 4.3 ) allows the use of b ≪ N . We empirically show that the efficiency of our approach, with none of the above optimizations, is still competitive for average data sets, thus implying batching alone is sufficient for scalability.

4. Experiments

4.1. Datasets

For the purpose of comparison, experiments are conducted on six common clustering benchmarks, which includes one image dataset (USPS [34] ), one sensor data dataset (HHAR [35] ), one text dataset (Reuters [36] ) and three citation graphs (ACM, CiteSeer, DBLP) following [6] , [11] , [19] . For the non-graph data, we use undirected k -nearest neighbor (KNN [37] ) to generate adjacency matrix A as in Bo et al. [6] , Peng et al. [11] . Table 1 summarizes the datasets.

4.2. Baseline methods

We compare with four types of methods, namely raw features: K-means [38] ; deep clustering using features only: AE [9] , DEC [21] , IDEC [10] ; deep clustering using feature and attention learnt structure : DAEGC [2] , AGCN [11] ; and deep clustering using feature and GCN learnt structure: GAE [12] , SDCN [6] . Our method, deep clustering using feature and structure learnt via loss, forms a distinct separate type.
Specifically, K-means [38] is a classical clustering method using raw data AE [9] applies K-means [38] to deep representations learned by an auto-encoder. DEC [21] , clusters data in a jointly optimized feature space. IDEC [10] enhances DEC by adding KL divergence based reconstruction loss. GAE [12] combines convolution with the AE. DAEGC [2] , uses an attentional neighbor-wise strategy and clustering loss. SDCN [6] , couples DEC and GCN via a fixed delivery operator and uses feature reconstruction AGCN [11] , extends SDCN by adding an attention based delivery operator and uses multi scale information for cluster prediction.
We use AGCN, which is the current state-of-the-art, as our benchmark. We did not include [39] because it requires augmented views of the entire Graph, and it is based on NCE contrastive loss. [3] incorporates the latent category information to reduce the intra-cluster variance but can only be used for image clustering. Also, DFCN [19] was omitted because its results for all 4 evaluation metrics of all 6 datasets are lower than AGCN, our benchmark.
We use Accuracy (ACC), Normalized Mutual Information (NMI), Average Rand Index (ARI), and macro F1-score (F1) for evaluation following [6] , [11] , [19] , our benchmarks and current state-of-the-art models. For each, larger values imply better clustering.

4.3. Implementation

SCGC does not require an adjacency matrix for feed forward. A once-only computed reference is used during training which is not required for inference. An indirect benefit is that SCGC can be trained in batches, facilitating scalability, without the need for full graph information, as in most conventional GNNs [6] , [11] , [14] . Batching can be implemented by randomly sampling B nodes taking the corresponding adjacency information A ̂ ∈ R B × B , pre-computed as in Eq. (1) for some R hop depth of influence and the node features X ∈ R R × d .
For fair comparison, we use the same 500-500-2000-10 AE dimensions and the same pre-training procedure as in [6] , [11] , i.e. 30 epochs; learning rate of 10 −3 for USPS, HHAR, ACM, DBLP and 10 −4 for REUT and CITE; batch size of 256 . We borrow the publicly available pre-trained AE from [6] .
For training, we initialize cluster centers using K -means. We set β = 10 for HHAR and 0.1 for others. Experiments are repeated 10 times with 200 epochs. We replicate the exact same training loops, including internal evaluation metric calls, when measuring performance for fair comparison.

4.4. Quantitative results

In Table 2 , we compare our results with state-of-the-art graph clustering methods [6] , [11] following identical procedures. Our hyperparameters ( α , K , τ ) in dataset order are (1,4,0.5), (1,4,2.25), (3,3,1), (0.5,2,0.25), (0.5,1,0.25), (1,1,0.25) for SCGC and (4,4,0.25), (1,3,2.25), (0.5,3,0.25), (1,1,0.25), (1,1,0.25), (1,1,0.25) for SCGC*. Learning rate is 10 −4 for CITE and 10 −3 for others. We observe the following:
  • •
    Our methods SCGC and SCGC* achieves best ACC on all six data sets. Specifically, a significant improvement of 20% on ARI and 18% on NMI on DBLP. In CITE, we improve by 14% and 12% on ARI and NMI respectively. In each, we improve ACC by 6.4% over state-of-the-art. In the USPS image dataset, SCGC* improves 5% while SCGC improves 2.4% on ACC respectively and SCGC* gains 8% on ARI, 5.7% on NMI and 5.1% on F1.
  • •
    SCGC is able to fuse multi-level node influences flexibly without using rigid layers, and without requiring to make prior assumptions on the latent node dependency structure. Further, all our model constraints are imposed softly; features are enforced with a soft reconstruction loss, structure is enforced with a soft contrastive loss and clustering is enforced with confidence promotion by KL divergence for soft assignment. Thus, by seamlessly combining these soft constraints, we can handle diverse data modalities and characteristics effectively.
  • •
    Generally, we achieve better results on the natural graph datasets; ACM, DBLP and CITE. This can be expected as the constructed KNN-based structures in the non-graph datasets may not correctly capture neighbor information. It also indicates the presence of more than simple similarity information in real-world graph structures, which can aid clustering and other downstream tasks.
  • •
    SDCN couples AE and GCN models together, AGCN improves on SDCN by adding attention based coupling, indicating the importance of a flexible or soft feature-structure fusion. We completely eliminate coupling, replacing it with a purely virtual guidance-based supervisory fusion. Further, while AGCN uses multi-scale features at fixed levels, there is still the assumption of a latent structure that needs to be matched with convolutional layers. We solve the aforementioned drawbacks to achieve state-of-the-art on all six data sets.
  • •
    We explain the poor performance on NMI, ARI and F1 in REUT data set by the fact that its graph quality is poor [11] , resulting in poor clustering performance. Also, its class imbalance (4312:2403:2471:814) can result in high ACC if most points fall into the same large cluster. In contrast, for all natural real world graphs performance improvement of our method is significant.
  • •
    Compared to SCGC, SCGC* achieves state-of-the-art by adopting Influence as the loss metric. Additionally, from Fig. 6 , SCGC* also has superior performance; overall 55% reduction in training time and overall, 81% reduction on inference time over the next best model.

4.5. Qualitative results

In order to have a visual understanding of the embeddings, we visualize them via UMAP [40] in Fig. 4 . Except for USPS, which is a distinct set of 0 ⋯ 9 handwritten digits, we see that all other data sets consist of quite indistinguishable clusters (first row). In the second row showing the pre-trained AE based feature embeddings, the clusters are still not separable, especially for the real-world graph data sets. Fusing structure via neighbor contrastivity and influence contrastivity in row three (SCGC) and four (SCGC*) respectively, results in a more cohesive and separable cluster formulation.

4.6. Ablation study on hyperparameters

In order to have a deeper understanding of the effect of hyperparameters in SCGC, we give an exhaustive analysis in Fig. 5 . We consider the hyperparameters of the contrastive loss from Eq. (12) : τ , α , R and LR, the learning rate. For the other hyperparameters, we have used the same settings as in our benchmarks [6] , [11] . Overall, we observe that (1) α and R are trivial hyperparameters as changes to these have a lesser effect on the results. Thus, SCGC is robust to changes in the mentioned hyperparameters. However, higher R values are slightly better, which suggests that incorporating more neighborhood influence is useful, which is the premise of SCGC*. (2) As τ decreases accuracy is consistently improved on all data sets, particularly on DBLP and USPS. (3) A learning rate of 0.001 performs well relative to 0.0001, which is a recommended default setting.

4.7. Performance

In Fig. 6 we compare the GPU training and inference timings. Our model times also include the time taken for the cumulative influence computation. For all the data sets, SCGC is superior, even without the use of batching mentioned in Section 4.3 . However, SCGC* shows a much more significant reduction in time, i.e., 27% reduction in training time and 47% reduction in inference time over SCGC. Its MLP-based design is lighter, the cluster centroids are better alternatives to the AE, and its IAC loss provides effective contrastive supervision. Additionally, in either model, inference does not need graph structure information, i.e., the adjacency matrix, which makes inference even faster. Also, for inference, time complexity is linearly related to the batch size. Further, inference can be trivially parallelized. In comparison, despite its theoretical quadratic train time complexity (Section 3.5 ), SCGC* averages 55% reduction in training time and 81% reduction in inference time over the second best model, AGCN. Thus, our models present strong efficiency advantages, in particular for resource constrained systems and edge-computing cases.

4.8. Future work

For comparison with prior work [6] , [11] , we chose to use the same AE with 500 − 500 − 2000 − 10 dimensions. However, further study is needed to determine an optimal AE to better handle the novel IAC loss, including diffident architectures (ex.: VAE [12] , VQVAE), different layer choices (ex.: [4] uses Gelu activation, Layer normalization, and dropouts) and bottleneck sizes.
SCGC has a time complexity of O ( N 2 ) , due to IAC loss, that can be reduced with batching or implementing a sparse version of the influence contrastive loss, or a suitable proxy or surrogate approach, which we leave for future work.

5. Conclusion

This paper introduces SCGC, which offers compelling advantages over traditional GNN based methods for graph clustering; ready accommodation of local, long-term or any mixed combination of node dependencies naturally, batch support, efficiency, linear inference complexity and trivial parallelizability. Further, we propose I nfluence A ugmented C ontrastive (IAC) loss, a novel Influence based augmentation-less edge-contrastive loss. IAC’s additive nature enables stronger inductive biases for generalization with a relaxed homophily assumption, without the need to approximate the latent dependency and relationship structure of complex graphs. Unlike prior deep clustering approaches that exploit multimodality, we show that a much simpler approach using only an optimization guided soft structure incorporation, is sufficient for better and efficient models. Using IAC, SCGC* achieves significant accuracy improvements over state-of-the-art and 55% and 81% overall reduction on training and inference times. In future work, we plan to address IAC’s quadratic time complexity limitation and explore different architectures, including transformers, with IAC loss. We hope our theoretical insights and superior empirical results with augmentation-less edge-contrastive learning and Influence will inspire and guide future model improvements in this direction.
